planets.description: Understand the course outcome and why elders’ stories matter.
planets.missionInstructions:
You’ll learn what the course will build together: a short interview podcast made by your team with an elder. This matters because it helps keep local stories alive and teaches listening, questioning and sharing skills.

Instructions

Step 1: Course overview

  • Read the course goal together and circle one thing you’re excited to learn.

Checkpoint: Now everyone knows the course goal and one personal reason to care.

Step 2: What is a podcast?

  • Listen to a 2–3 minute sample interview podcast (teacher plays it).

Checkpoint: You can name one thing a podcast does (tell a story, share a voice).

Step 3: Team formation

  • Form teams of 2–4 and pick a team name.

Checkpoint: Your team has a name and members.

You’ve seen the project and formed your team. Next, you'll practice listening to real voices to learn what makes a good interview.
planets.title: 1.1: Meet the Project

planets.missionInstructions:
Before interviewing, we learn how to show respect and follow community protocols. This helps keep relationships strong and builds trust for better stories.

Instructions

Step 1: What respect looks like

  • In your team, list 5 things to do when meeting an elder (e.g., greet, listen, ask politely).

Checkpoint: You have a short list of respectful behaviours to follow.

Step 2: Talking about consent

  • Teacher explains consent: what it is and why we ask permission before recording.

Checkpoint: You can say why we ask permission before recording someone.

Step 3: Role-play a respectful meeting

  • With a partner, role-play greeting an elder and asking to record for the podcast.

Checkpoint: You practiced a respectful, clear way to ask for permission.

You now understand respect and consent—essential for working with elders. Next, you’ll start thinking about who to interview.
planets.title: 1.2: Values & Respect for Elders
planets.description: Learn respectful behaviour, cultural protocols, and basic consent ideas for working with elders.

planets.title: 1.3: Pick an Elder & Story Focus
planets.description: Choose an elder to invite and decide what story angle your team will explore.
planets.missionInstructions:
Picking the right elder and a clear focus helps your interview be meaningful. A focus is a short idea about what you want to learn from them.

Instructions

Step 1: Brainstorm elders

  • Each team lists 6 elders they could invite and one reason each elder’s story matters.

Checkpoint: Your team has 6 possible elders and reasons why they matter.

Step 2: Choose a story focus

  • Pick one focus (example: childhood games, food traditions, or a life change) and write it in one sentence.

Checkpoint: You have a one-sentence focus that will guide your questions.

Step 3: Get teacher approval & note next steps

  • Tell the teacher your chosen elder and focus so they can help with permission and scheduling.

Checkpoint: Teacher knows your team’s plan and will help contact the elder.

You’re set with a chosen elder and a clear focus. Next week we learn how to listen like a journalist.

Teams work best when roles are clear. Today you’ll name roles and make a short plan so everyone knows what to do each week.

Instructions

Step 1: Role explanation

  • Teacher explains common roles: interviewer, co-interviewer/listener, recorder/tech, note-taker, editor.

Checkpoint: You know what each role does.

Step 2: Assign roles

  • Team members pick their roles for at least the first two weeks.

Checkpoint: Roles are assigned and written down.

Step 3: Build a simple timeline

  • Create a one-page schedule for the next four weeks with who will do which tasks each day.

Checkpoint: You have a clear mini-plan to follow for the next month.

Team roles and a timeline are set. You’re organised and ready to practice listening and questioning next week.
planets.description: Assign team roles (e.g., interviewer, recorder, note-taker, editor) and make a simple timeline.
planets.title: 1.4: Personal roles & simple schedule

stars.title: Week 1: Getting Grounded — Purpose, Teams & Respect
stars.description: Form teams, learn course goals, and build a respectful approach to interviewing elders and community stories.
Train ears by listening to local stories and short interviews. Learn to spot good story moments and what makes a question work.
stars.title: Week 2: Listen & Learn — Critical Listening Skills

planets.title: 2.1: Active Listening Practice
planets.description: Practice really listening and summarising short audio clips.
planets.missionInstructions:
Active listening helps you notice details and follow-up ideas during an interview. We’ll practice with short clips and group sharing.

Instructions

Step 1: Micro-teach — Active listening

  • Teacher: Active listening means giving attention, not interrupting, and noticing details we can ask more about.

Checkpoint: You know what active listening looks like.

Step 2: Listen to a clip

  • Listen to a 1–2 minute local story or interview excerpt.

Checkpoint: You heard the clip and are ready to talk about it.

Step 3: Summarise

  • In your team, write a one-sentence summary of the main idea and one surprising detail.

Checkpoint: You can summarise and find details to explore.

Active listening will help you ask better follow-ups during your interview. Next day we practise different question types.

planets.title: 2.2: Question Types — Open, Closed, Probes
planets.missionInstructions:
Good interviews use open questions and probes to invite longer answers and memories. You’ll learn the difference and write your own examples.

Instructions

Step 1: Micro-teach — Question types

  • Teacher: An open question invites a story (e.g., "What was it like?"). A closed question gets a short fact (e.g., "Did that happen in 1990?"). Probes are short follow-ups (e.g., "Can you tell me more?").

Checkpoint: You can name three kinds of questions and when to use them.

Step 2: Transform closed to open

  • Convert 5 closed questions into open versions in your team.

Checkpoint: You made closed questions into open invites for story.

Step 3: Practice probe questions

  • With partners, role-play an answer and practise using 3 different probe questions.

Checkpoint: You can ask follow-up probes that encourage more detail.

You now know how to ask open questions and probes — essential tools for your interviews.
planets.description: Learn and practise open vs closed questions and probe questions that invite stories.
Learn to spot story ‘moments’ (details, emotions, turning points) to shape your final episode.
planets.missionInstructions:
A story has moments that matter. Today you’ll identify moments in short clips and decide which moments your team wants to capture in the elder interview.

Instructions

Step 1: Micro-teach — Story moment

  • Teacher: A story moment is a small scene or detail that reveals something important (a memory, a surprising fact, or strong feeling).

Checkpoint: You know what a story moment is.

Step 2: Mark moments

  • Listen to a clip and write down 3 moments (one sentence each) you could use in a podcast.

Checkpoint: You found moments that could become part of a story.

Step 3: Team selection

  • Choose the top 2 moments your team wants to try to capture in your elder’s interview.

Checkpoint: Your team has two target moments to look for in the elder’s story.

You can now hear and pick story moments — this will guide your questions and editing choices later.
planets.title: 2.3: Story Moments & Beats

planets.description: Begin a listening log where students note interesting phrasing, details, and questions for their elder.
planets.title: 2.4: Listening Log
planets.missionInstructions:
A listening log captures things you notice and ideas to ask an elder about. Keep it short and useful for later.

Instructions

Step 1: Set up the log

  • Create a 1-page listening log template with columns: clip, moment, words to remember, follow-up question.

Checkpoint: You have a listening log template ready.

Step 2: Add three entries

  • Add 3 entries from clips you heard this week (one sentence each).

Checkpoint: Your log has 3 useful entries to inspire questions.

Step 3: Share one entry

  • Share one entry with another team and get one quick suggestion to improve it.

Checkpoint: You improved one entry using feedback.

Your listening log will grow throughout the course and help you build questions and edits later.

planets.title: 3.1: Build an Interview Map
planets.description: Create a loose roadmap of topics and sequence for your interview (opening, middle, closing).
planets.missionInstructions:
An interview map helps the conversation flow. Think of it as a road with stops: warm-up, main memories, and wrap-up.

Instructions

Step 1: Micro-teach — Interview map

  • Teacher: An interview map lists topics in order so you can guide the elder naturally from easy questions to deeper stories.

Checkpoint: You know what an interview map does.

Step 2: Create your map

  • Write your team’s interview map: 1–2 opening questions, 4–6 main topic points, 2 closing questions.

Checkpoint: Your team has a clear roadmap for the conversation.

Step 3: Quick check

  • Swap maps with another team and give one suggestion for improvement.

Checkpoint: Your map is tightened after peer feedback.

With an interview map you’ll be able to guide the conversation confidently and capture story moments.

planets.title: 3.2: Crafting Opening Questions
planets.missionInstructions:
Openers should be simple, respectful, and invite a safe memory. We’ll write and test short openings.

Instructions

Step 1: Micro-teach — Good openers

  • Teacher: A good opener is short, friendly, and connected to your focus (e.g., "Can you tell us about the place you grew up?").

Checkpoint: You know the qualities of a good opening question.

Step 2: Write three openers

  • Draft three different opening questions in your team.

Checkpoint: You have three opening questions to choose from.

Step 3: Peer test

  • Role-play your opening with another team and note which version felt easiest to answer.

Checkpoint: You selected an opening that feels natural to answer.

You have polished opening questions to help the elder relax and start telling their story.
planets.description: Write opening questions that build trust and ease the elder into the interview.

planets.title: 3.3: Writing Story Questions
planets.description: Create main questions that invite specific memories, images, and emotions.
planets.missionInstructions:
Main questions get into details and feelings. Use sensory prompts (what, where, who, how did you feel) to help elders describe moments.

Instructions

Step 1: Micro-teach — Sensory and specific prompts

  • Teacher: Ask 'what did you see/hear/smell?' or 'who was there?' to get vivid answers.

Checkpoint: You can name sensory prompts that evoke detail.

Step 2: Write 6 main questions

  • Draft 6 main story questions using sensory prompts tied to your focus.

Checkpoint: Your team has 6 strong questions to guide deep answers.

Step 3: Sequence your questions

  • Order the 6 questions on your interview map so they flow from easy to deep.

Checkpoint: Your questions are in a natural order for conversation.

You’re ready to practise asking these questions naturally in short interviews.

Closings wrap up the interview respectfully and give the elder a chance to add anything else. Practice a short closing that thanks them and invites a last thought.

Instructions

Step 1: Micro-teach — Closing purpose

  • Teacher: A closing gives gratitude and a final moment to share any message the elder would like listeners to hear.

Checkpoint: You know why closings matter.

Step 2: Draft closers

  • Write two closing questions or comments (e.g., "Is there anything you’d like young people to know?").

Checkpoint: You have closing lines ready for the interview.

Step 3: Practice a smooth exit

  • Role-play a closing and the moment you stop recording, practicing thanks and next steps.

Checkpoint: You can close an interview politely and clearly.

Closings will help your interviews end on a kind and meaningful note when you meet elders for real.
planets.title: 3.4: Closing Questions & Safe Exits
planets.description: Prepare respectful closing questions and a way to end the conversation positively.

stars.title: Week 3: Question Design & Interview Planning
stars.description: Craft a clear interview plan, write strong questions, and practise short interviews.
Learn local interview protocols, language options, and how to incorporate Cook Islands Māori respectfully.
stars.title: Week 4: Cultural Protocols & Language Choices

planets.description: Discuss local norms, introductions, family permissions, and any required cultural practices when visiting elders.
planets.missionInstructions:
Local protocols differ by island and family. Today we list the respectful steps to follow when visiting an elder at home or on land.

Instructions

Step 1: Group discussion

  • In a circle, each student shares one local protocol they know about visiting elders.

Checkpoint: The class has a combined list of local protocols.

Step 2: Compile best practices

  • As a class, create a short ‘visiting checklist’ (greeting, small gift or offering, ask permission to record, thank-you).

Checkpoint: You have a visiting checklist to use before each interview.

Step 3: Teacher adds safety and consent notes

  • Teacher explains where to record permission (written/recorded) and any school or community consent steps.

Checkpoint: You know basic consent steps and who to tell at school if needed.

You now have a respectful checklist for meeting elders. Next we choose language options for your episode.
planets.title: 4.1: Community Protocols
4.2: Language Choice & Mixing Languages
planets.description: Decide if your interview will use English, Cook Islands Māori, or both and how to handle translations or code-switching.
planets.missionInstructions:
Language choice affects who can listen and how meaning carries. Teams should plan if they will interview in one language, mix both, or record bilingual segments.

Instructions

Step 1: Micro-teach — Language options

  • Teacher: You can record in Cook Islands Māori, English, or both. If mixing, plan short translations or notes to help listeners.

Checkpoint: You understand the language options and their effects.

Step 2: Team decision

  • Decide as a team which language(s) you will use and why (audience, elder comfort).

Checkpoint: Your team has chosen your language approach.

Step 3: Plan for translations

  • If using multiple languages, plan how you’ll translate or add short English summaries for key lines.

Checkpoint: You have a simple plan for translations or summaries if needed.

Language choices are set. Next we’ll practice respectful introductions in your chosen language(s).

A clear, warm introduction helps elders understand who you are and why you’re there. Practice in the language you plan to use.

Instructions

Step 1: Draft introduction

  • Write a 20–30 second introduction (team name, why you’re recording, how the elder can stop anytime).

Checkpoint: You have a draft introduction ready.

Step 2: Translate if needed

  • Translate the introduction into the elder’s language or prepare a short bilingual intro.

Checkpoint: You have an introduction in the chosen language(s).

Step 3: Rehearse aloud

  • Practice the intro with your team until it sounds natural and respectful.

Checkpoint: Your team can deliver the introduction naturally.

You’re ready to use a respectful introduction when contacting or meeting your elder.
planets.title: 4.3: Practise Introductions in Chosen Language(s)
planets.description: Write and rehearse a short introduction and greeting to use with the elder in the agreed language(s).
Create a short consent script and a plan for written or recorded permission suitable for elders and families.
planets.missionInstructions:
Consent can be verbal (recorded) or written. Today you’ll make a short, clear consent script to use before recording and practice getting permission.

Instructions

Step 1: Draft consent script

  • Write a clear one-paragraph consent script explaining the project, how the audio will be used, and that they can stop anytime.

Checkpoint: You have a consent script that explains the project simply.

Step 2: Teacher reviews for child-safety

  • Give the script to the teacher for review to ensure it meets school / community safety rules.

Checkpoint: Your consent script is checked and approved by the teacher.

Step 3: Practice recording consent

  • Role-play asking for consent and recording the elder saying yes, and practise what to do if they say no.

Checkpoint: Your team can confidently request and record consent respectfully.

You now have a consent script and practice for asking permission. Next week you’ll learn smartphone recording basics.
planets.title: 4.4: Consent in Practice

planets.missionInstructions:
You’ll become comfortable with the phone used for recording — how to start/stop, name files, and where recordings are saved.

Instructions

Step 1: App tour

  • Open the phone’s recorder app and show where to start, stop, and save a file.

Checkpoint: You can start and stop recordings and find saved files on the phone.

Step 2: Naming files

  • Record a short test clip and name it with your team name and date.

Checkpoint: Your test file is saved with a clear name you can find.

Step 3: Quality check

  • Teacher explains basic quality choices (use highest quality available) and students select the setting.

Checkpoint: Your app is set to a good quality setting for interviews.

You can use the recorder app and save files properly. Next we learn how to get the best sound using simple techniques.
planets.title: 5.1: Phone Recorder App & Settings
planets.description: Open the phone’s recorder app and learn basic settings (file names, sample quality if available).

planets.missionInstructions:
Where the mic is matters. Small moves change how voices sound. You’ll practise holding the phone and using a small stand or soft cushion.

Instructions

Step 1: Micro-teach — Mic distance

  • Teacher: For clear voice recording, hold the mic 15–30 cm from the speaker’s mouth and slightly off-axis (not directly in front) to reduce breath pops.

Checkpoint: You know the recommended mic distance and angle.

Step 2: Practise positions

  • In pairs, practise holding the phone 15–30 cm from a speaker while recording a short sentence.

Checkpoint: You can position the phone to capture a clear voice without handling noise.

Step 3: Test and listen

  • Play back your test recording and note any handling sounds; try again to fix them.

Checkpoint: Your team can record with minimal handling noise and clear voice.

You can now position the phone to get good sound. Next, we learn how to find quiet locations and control background noise.
planets.title: 5.2: Mic Position & Handling
planets.description: Learn where to hold the phone or external mic for clear sound and how to avoid handling noise.
Learn how to pick a quiet place and how ambient sound can help a story when used intentionally.
planets.missionInstructions:
Background noise can hurt clarity but sometimes small ambient sounds add feeling. Today you’ll identify good places and practise capturing ambient sound for transitions.

Instructions

Step 1: Micro-teach — Ambient vs noise

  • Teacher: Ambient sound gives context (waves, birds). Noise distracts (traffic, loud talking). Use ambient sound sparsely as a storytelling tool.

Checkpoint: You can tell the difference between useful ambient sound and distracting noise.

Step 2: Scout and list

  • Walk around school and pick two quiet spots and one spot with useful ambient sound; write notes about why each is good or bad.

Checkpoint: You have three candidate recording spots and reasons for each.

Step 3: Capture ambient

  • Record a 15–30 second ambient clip from the useful spot to use later as a transition.

Checkpoint: You captured an ambient sound clip that adds place and feeling.

You can find quiet places and capture helpful ambient sound. Next, practise levels and monitoring audio quality while recording.
planets.title: 5.3: Finding Quiet Locations & Ambient Sound

planets.missionInstructions:
If audio is too loud it clips and becomes unusable. You’ll practise keeping levels safe by moving the phone and checking recordings.

Instructions

Step 1: Micro-teach — Clipping

  • Teacher: Clipping happens when sound is too loud and turns distorted. Avoid loud bursts; listen for crackling.

Checkpoint: You know what clipping sounds like and why to avoid it.

Step 2: Test loudness

  • Record a student saying a normal sentence and a loud sentence; listen for distortion.

Checkpoint: You can hear if a recording is distorted.

Step 3: Adjust distance

  • If the loud test distorted, move the mic further away and record again until both normal and loud lines sound clear.

Checkpoint: You can adjust mic distance to prevent clipping while keeping clear sound.

You can manage basic recording levels. Next week you’ll begin mock interviews using these techniques.
planets.description: Learn to watch levels (peaks and clipping) and do simple checks to avoid distorted recordings.
planets.title: 5.4: Audio Levels & Monitoring

stars.title: Week 5: Smartphone Recording Basics
stars.description: Learn how to use a smartphone to record clear audio: mic handling, quiet spaces, levels, and simple accessories.

stars.title: Week 6: Interview Practice — Mock Interviews

planets.missionInstructions:
A short practice interview helps you apply opening questions and mic skills under low pressure. Treat your partner like an elder for practice.

Instructions

Step 1: Prepare gear

  • Set up your phone in record mode and check file name and location.

Checkpoint: Your recorder is ready to capture the practice interview.

Step 2: Conduct the 5-minute interview

  • Run a 5-minute interview using your opening and 1–2 main questions while the rest of the team observes.

Checkpoint: You completed a short recorded interview practicing roles.

Step 3: Playback & feedback

  • Listen to the recording together and note one strong moment and one improvement.

Checkpoint: You identified one success and one improvement from the practice clip.

You’ve done a short interview and heard it back. Next practice will focus on follow-up and listening.
planets.description: Record a 5-minute in-class interview using your opening questions and phone techniques.
planets.title: 6.1: Mini Interview 1 — Warm-up

planets.description: Practice using probe questions to follow-up on interesting moments during a 7–10 minute interview.
planets.missionInstructions:
Good interviews follow where the story leads. Today we practise hearing a detail and asking a probe that opens the memory deeper.

Instructions

Step 1: Plan probes

  • Pick three likely probe questions from your listening log that match your main questions.

Checkpoint: You have three probe questions ready to use.

Step 2: Conduct a 7–10 minute interview

  • Run a 7–10 minute interview and deliberately use at least two probes after an interesting detail.

Checkpoint: You practiced using probes to deepen a response.

Step 3: Review moments

  • Pick one moment from the recording that improved because of a probe and explain why.

Checkpoint: You can see how probes changed the interview’s depth.

You practiced following the story. Next you'll practise technical set-up and problem handling.
planets.title: 6.2: Mini Interview 2 — Probing & Follow-ups
6.3: Troubleshooting & On-the-spot Fixes
planets.description: Learn quick fixes for common problems: phone battery, ambient noise, interruptions.
planets.missionInstructions:
Problems can happen during real recordings. Learn fast fixes so you can stay calm if something goes wrong with an elder present.

Instructions

Step 1: List common issues

  • In your team, list the top 5 problems that might happen during an interview (battery, calls, noise).

Checkpoint: You can name five likely issues and why they matter.

Step 2: Create quick solutions

  • For each problem, write one quick action you can take right away (e.g., airplane mode to avoid calls).

Checkpoint: You have immediate fixes for the five problems.

Step 3: Role-play a problem

  • Role-play a short interruption (dog barking, phone call) and practise your team’s response.

Checkpoint: You know how to stay calm and fix a problem during recording.

You’re better prepared for real interviews and can handle small issues without panicking. Next week you’ll do a supervised short field interview if possible.

Feedback helps you improve quickly. Use a short rubric focused on clarity, respect, and story moments to give feedback after each practice.

Instructions

Step 1: Introduce a simple rubric

  • Teacher shares a 3-point rubric: (1) Respect & protocol, (2) Questioning & listening, (3) Audio quality.

Checkpoint: You understand the 3-point rubric categories.

Step 2: Give feedback

  • After each practice interview, teams give one positive and one suggestion using the rubric.

Checkpoint: You’ve provided and received constructive feedback with the rubric.

Step 3: Note improvements

  • Update your team notes with one action you will change for the next recording.

Checkpoint: You have a concrete improvement plan for your next interview.

Feedback cycles will keep your interviews improving. Next weeks build towards a short community practice interview.
planets.description: Give and receive feedback using a simple rubric to improve interviewing and technical skills.
planets.title: 6.4: Peer Feedback Cycle

stars.description: Practice short interviews with classmates, focusing on question flow, listening, and recording technique.

stars.title: Week 7: Short Field Interviews — Putting Skills into Practice
stars.description: Conduct short (10–15 min) supervised interviews with an elder or community member to capture real material and practice etiquette.

planets.title: 7.1: Final Prep for Field Visit
planets.description: Confirm roles, charge phones, print consent, and rehearse introductions before leaving school.
planets.missionInstructions:
Preparation reduces stress during a field visit. Today check gear and practise your full introduction and consent process.

Instructions

Step 1: Gear checklist

  • Check phone battery, recorder app, spare battery/charger, and your consent script printed or ready on a phone.

Checkpoint: All essential gear is checked and ready.

Step 2: Rehearse the whole start

  • Rehearse your introduction, consent script, and first question as a team.

Checkpoint: Your team can deliver the introduction and consent calmly.

Step 3: Teacher sign-off

  • Teacher reviews your plan and gives permission to go on the short field visit.

Checkpoint: You have teacher approval to visit the elder (supervised as required).

You’re prepared to visit an elder for a short supervised interview. Remember respect and consent at all times.

This is your chance to use everything you’ve practised: introductions, mic skills, active listening, and probes. Aim to capture at least one vivid moment for your final podcast.

Instructions

Step 1: Set up and greet

  • Greet the elder using your visiting checklist and deliver your prepared introduction.

Checkpoint: The elder knows who you are and why you are recording.

Step 2: Get consent recorded

  • Ask for permission on record and have the elder say yes if they agree; note any wishes (e.g., sections they don’t want shared).

Checkpoint: You have recorded the elder’s consent and any restrictions.

Step 3: Conduct 10–15 min interview

  • Conduct the interview focusing on one or two of your planned moments and using probes when interesting details appear.

Checkpoint: You recorded a 10–15 minute interview with at least one strong moment captured.

You completed a real interview! Back at school you’ll review the audio and pick the best clips to shape a story.
planets.title: 7.2: Field Interview — Short Recording
planets.description: Conduct a 10–15 minute interview with an elder (supervised). Focus on comfort, clarity and capturing one strong story moment.

planets.title: 7.3: Immediate Review & Backup
planets.missionInstructions:
Right after an interview, it’s important to check the recording and back it up to avoid losing the material.

Instructions

Step 1: Quick listen

  • Listen to the first minute and one strong moment to check clarity and that consent was captured.

Checkpoint: You confirmed the recording has clear audio and consent was captured.

Step 2: Take notes

  • Note timestamps of the best moments and any parts the elder asked to keep private.

Checkpoint: You have time-stamped notes identifying strong clips and restrictions.

Step 3: Backup the file

  • Copy the audio file to a teacher-approved backup location (school drive or another phone) and confirm it opened there.

Checkpoint: Your recording is safely backed up and accessible.

Your interview is secure and logged. Next week you will learn to edit and select story clips.
planets.description: Listen back to the recording, make quick notes, and make a backup copy of the file.
Send a thank-you and plan any follow-up with the elder or family as appropriate.
planets.title: 7.4: Reflection & Respectful Follow-up
planets.missionInstructions:
After the visit, being grateful and clear about next steps keeps trust strong. Plan a short thank-you and how you’ll share the finished podcast outcome.

Instructions

Step 1: Write a short thank-you

  • Draft a 1–2 sentence thank-you message your team will send or say to the elder within 48 hours.

Checkpoint: You have a polite thank-you message ready.

Step 2: Plan follow-up

  • Note any promises made (e.g., send final clip) and assign who will handle each promise.

Checkpoint: Your team has a clear follow-up plan with names and tasks.

Step 3: Teacher check-in

  • Tell the teacher how the interview went and confirm next steps for editing and release.

Checkpoint: Teacher knows the outcome and next editing timeline.

You’ve closed the interview respectfully and planned next steps for editing and sharing the story.

stars.description: Learn basic mobile editing: trimming clips, arranging story order, and saving edits. Build a rough story from field audio.
stars.title: Week 8: Intro to Editing on Smartphones

planets.description: Open and explore a simple phone editing app available (teacher suggests and installs one).
planets.title: 8.1: Choose an Editing App & Tour
planets.missionInstructions:
Editing turns recorded pieces into a story. Today you’ll meet a phone editor and learn where to trim and move clips.

Instructions

Step 1: App micro-teach

  • Teacher introduces the chosen mobile editor and explains trim, cut, and save functions in 1–2 sentences.

Checkpoint: You know which app you’ll use and its basic tools.

Step 2: Open your field file

  • Import your team’s interview file into the app.

Checkpoint: Your recording is loaded into the editor.

Step 3: Try a simple trim

  • Trim the start and end of the interview to remove silence and save the trimmed clip as a new file.

Checkpoint: You saved a trimmed version of your interview.

You can open and trim your audio on a phone. Next you’ll find and extract the best story moments.

planets.title: 8.2: Marking & Extracting Story Clips
planets.missionInstructions:
Editing is choosing which moments tell your story. You’ll mark the best clips and export them as short pieces to arrange later.

Instructions

Step 1: Micro-teach — Clip selection

  • Teacher: Choose clips that show vivid details and fit your focus — aim for 3–6 clips, each 10–40 seconds.

Checkpoint: You know how many and what length clips to aim for.

Step 2: Mark timestamps

  • Use your listening notes to mark timestamps of 3–6 candidate clips in the editor.

Checkpoint: You’ve marked 3–6 candidate clips with timestamps.

Step 3: Export clips

  • Cut and export each chosen clip as its own small file, labelled with the clip purpose (e.g., 'childhood memory 01').

Checkpoint: You have separate clip files for the top story moments.

You now have a library of short clips to assemble into your episode structure.
planets.description: Identify and cut out the best moments from your interview to use in a story edit.

planets.missionInstructions:
A storyboard arranges your clips to create a beginning, middle and end. You’ll try a few orders to find the strongest flow.

Instructions

Step 1: Micro-teach — Story arc

  • Teacher: A short arc: set the scene (intro), show the main memory(s) (body), and end with a reflection or message (closer).

Checkpoint: You understand the simple three-part story arc for a short episode.

Step 2: Drag clips into order

  • In the editor, drag your exported clips into an order that follows the arc.

Checkpoint: You built a first rough order of clips in the editor.

Step 3: Add short transitions

  • Insert your ambient sounds or short team voiceovers where needed to connect clips.

Checkpoint: Your rough storyboard plays as a short, connected sequence.

You have a rough story order. Next week you’ll polish timing, add music, and learn to balance volume.
planets.title: 8.3: Arrange a Rough Storyboard
planets.description: Place clips into a rough order (intro, body, closer) to see how the story flows.
Learn to save project versions so you can return to earlier edits without losing work.
planets.missionInstructions:
Saving versions prevents accidental loss of changes. Today you’ll create named versions (drafts) of your edit and back them up.

Instructions

Step 1: Micro-teach — Versioning

  • Teacher: Versioning means saving copies labeled 'draft 1', 'draft 2' so you can return to earlier edits if needed.

Checkpoint: You know why versioning keeps your work safe.

Step 2: Save draft 1

  • Save your current project as 'draft 1' and export a backup copy to the teacher-approved drive.

Checkpoint: You created a saved draft and a backup export.

Step 3: Note changes

  • Write one sentence describing what you will change in ‘draft 2’.

Checkpoint: You have a clear plan to improve the next draft.

Your editing work is safe with versioned backups. Next week you’ll refine clips and learn mixing basics.
planets.title: 8.4: Save Versions & Backups

stars.title: Week 9: Polishing — Mixing, Music & Rights

planets.missionInstructions:
Balancing makes sure all voices sound like they belong together. Today you’ll adjust volume of clips so listeners don’t have to change their volume.

Instructions

Step 1: Micro-teach — Normalising & gain

  • Teacher: Normalising raises clip volume to a safe level. Gain adjusts volume; do small changes and listen.

Checkpoint: You know what normalising and gain do in simple terms.

Step 2: Listen for dips and peaks

  • Play your sequence and note which clips sound quieter or louder than others.

Checkpoint: You can identify uneven clips by ear.

Step 3: Adjust volumes

  • Use the editor’s volume tool to bring voice clips to a similar loudness and save as a new draft.

Checkpoint: Your voices now sound more even in the draft.

Your audio levels are balanced. Next you’ll carefully add music or ambient beds while respecting rights and elder wishes.
planets.description: Learn simple mixing: adjust clip volumes so voices are even and easy to hear.
planets.title: 9.1: Balance & Levels in the Editor

planets.description: Choose music (royalty-free or teacher-provided) and learn how to add subtle music beneath voices, lowering it when someone speaks.
planets.title: 9.2: Music & Ambient Beds — Use Carefully
planets.missionInstructions:
Music adds feeling but should not cover a speaker’s voice. You’ll pick short music and learn how to duck it under spoken clips.

Instructions

Step 1: Micro-teach — Music rights

  • Teacher: Only use music you have the right to use — teacher will provide approved music or use free/creative commons tracks.

Checkpoint: You understand to only use teacher-approved or free music.

Step 2: Pick a short bed

  • Choose one short music bed from teacher-approved options that matches your story mood.

Checkpoint: You selected a suitable, approved music clip.

Step 3: Add and duck

  • Place the music under an intro or transition and lower (duck) its volume during spoken clips so voices are clear.

Checkpoint: Music plays where intended and never covers voices.

Music enhances your story without overpowering voices. Next we add short titles, credits, and protective metadata about permissions.

Titles and credits tell listeners where the story came from and who helped. Metadata helps your teacher manage consent and rights.

Instructions

Step 1: Draft a title

  • Brainstorm three short episode titles that reflect your focus and pick one.

Checkpoint: You have a clear episode title.

Step 2: Write a short description

  • Write a 1–2 sentence description of the episode and the language(s) used.

Checkpoint: You have a description ready to share with listeners.

Step 3: Compile credits & permissions

  • In one short list, note the elder’s name (as they want credited), translator (if used), music source, and confirmation of consent.

Checkpoint: You have a credit list and consent note to keep with the file.

Your episode has a title, description, and credits. Next week you’ll record your final interview with the elder (longer and polished).
planets.title: 9.3: Titles, Credits & Metadata
planets.description: Create an episode title, short description, and add credits (who was interviewed, translators, music source, and teacher supervision).

planets.missionInstructions:
A quick review can catch things you missed. Use the rubric to get specific feedback about story clarity, respect, and audio quality.

Instructions

Step 1: Export a listenable draft

  • Export a low-size MP3 or similar file labelled 'near-final' and upload to the teacher area for review.

Checkpoint: Your draft is exported and accessible to teacher and peers.

Step 2: Peer listening

  • Swap drafts with one other team and use the 3-point rubric to give one strength and one suggestion.

Checkpoint: You received peer feedback with a clear improvement suggestion.

Step 3: Teacher feedback

  • Meet with the teacher for a 5-minute check to confirm consent, language decisions, and any content notes.

Checkpoint: Teacher confirmed your draft’s readiness for final recording or named areas to fix.

You’ve had a feedback round and know final edits needed before the long interview next week.
planets.description: Share your near-final draft with the teacher and another team for feedback using the classroom rubric.
planets.title: 9.4: Review with Teacher & Peer Check

stars.description: Refine clip timing, balance volumes, add short music or ambient beds, and understand basic rights for music and elder permissions.
Conduct the main long interview (20–40 minutes) with the elder, capturing material for the final 8–12 minute podcast episode.
stars.title: Week 10: Final Interview — The Long Recording

planets.description: Confirm logistics, roles, and do a final rehearsal including the full introduction and consent recording.
planets.missionInstructions:
A longer interview needs more preparation. Confirm schedule, travel, who leads which sections, and do a full rehearsal -- including consent and battery checks.

Instructions

Step 1: Confirm schedule

  • Confirm the appointment time with the elder (teacher helped coordinate) and confirm who will go from the team.

Checkpoint: You have a confirmed time and people assigned for the interview.

Step 2: Full run-through

  • Rehearse the entire start: greeting, intro, consent script, and the first 3 questions aloud.

Checkpoint: Your team delivered the start smoothly in rehearsal.

Step 3: Final gear check

  • Charge phones, bring backups, printed consent, and any translator if needed.

Checkpoint: All gear and supports are ready for the long interview.

You are ready for the long interview. Stay calm, respectful, and listen closely for story moments.
planets.title: 10.1: Final Prep & Rehearsal

planets.description: Conduct and record the full interview (aim 20–40 minutes), capturing a range of memories and reflections.
planets.title: 10.2: Record the Long Interview
planets.missionInstructions:
This is the main recording for your episode. Use your map but be ready to follow interesting threads and ask respectful probes.

Instructions

Step 1: Greeting and consent

  • Greet the elder with your visiting checklist, deliver the introduction, and record verbal consent on the phone.

Checkpoint: Consent is recorded and everyone is ready to start.

Step 2: Conduct the interview

  • Conduct the interview using your planned questions, ask probes when interesting details appear, and keep an ear for moments to timestamp.

Checkpoint: You captured a long interview with multiple moments to choose from.

Step 3: Wrap up respectfully

  • Close the interview with your planned closing, thank the elder, and confirm any agreed follow-up.

Checkpoint: You ended the interview respectfully and clearly.

You recorded the main interview! Back at school you'll mark the best moments and start final editing.

planets.description: Listen for key moments, timestamp them, and back up all files safely.
planets.title: 10.3: Immediate Backup & Logging
planets.missionInstructions:
Immediately after a long interview, create a safety copy and a timestamped log of promising moments for editing.

Instructions

Step 1: Quick listen for quality

  • Play the first minute and a few sections to ensure the file is clear and consent is present.

Checkpoint: You confirmed audio clarity and that consent is recorded.

Step 2: Timestamp top 8 moments

  • Note timestamps for up to 8 interesting moments with a one-line note about why each matters.

Checkpoint: You have a timestamped list of candidate clips for the final episode.

Step 3: Back up the master file

  • Back up the full interview to the teacher-approved drive and mark the backup location in your team notes.

Checkpoint: The master interview file is safely backed up and noted.

You secured the master recording and found many moments to use. Next week you’ll finalize the edit into the finished episode.

Keeping the elder informed and thanked strengthens community relations. Today you’ll prepare a finished thank-you and tell them how they’ll be included in the final event.

Instructions

Step 1: Prepare a thank-you note

  • Write a respectful thank-you note (short) to give to the elder or their family, including when they can hear the final episode.

Checkpoint: You have a clear thank-you note to share.

Step 2: Confirm permissions for sharing

  • Confirm with the elder if they are happy for the episode to be shared at a school event or online, following their wishes.

Checkpoint: You have clear permission for how the episode may be shared.

Step 3: Schedule a courtesy playback

  • Offer a date for a private or public playback and note it in your team plan.

Checkpoint: A courtesy playback date is scheduled or planned.

You have thanked the elder and clarified sharing wishes. Next week you’ll finish editing and prepare the final episode for the community.
planets.description: Send a formal thank-you and note how and when the elder will hear or see the final episode.
planets.title: 10.4: Thank-you & Community Notice

stars.title: Week 11: Final Post-Production & Show Notes

planets.missionInstructions:
Now you pick the best clips that fit your narrative and add short team-led voice links that help the story flow from one clip to another.

Instructions

Step 1: Pick clips for 8–12 min target

  • From your timestamp list, choose clips that together will result in an 8–12 minute episode.

Checkpoint: You selected clips to match the target episode length and focus.

Step 2: Write short linking lines

  • Draft 3–4 short team voice lines (10–20 seconds each) to introduce or connect clips.

Checkpoint: You have bridging lines that make the story clearer.

Step 3: Record the team voiceovers

  • Record your linking lines using the same mic technique and add them to the edit in the right places.

Checkpoint: Your linking lines are recorded and placed into the edit.

You have a finished story shape with bridging narration. Next you’ll do a polishing pass and make final exports.
planets.description: Choose the final clips from your timestamp list and tighten the episode’s spoken flow with short team voiceovers if needed.
planets.title: 11.1: Select Final Clips & Tighten Script
11.2: Final Polish — Fades, EQ, and Clean-up
planets.description: Do small edits: fade music, remove obvious breaths or clicks, and make the episode smooth to listen to.
planets.missionInstructions:
A careful polish fixes small things that distract. Today we remove pops, add fades between clips and ensure the episode flows smoothly.

Instructions

Step 1: Micro-teach — Fade & clean

  • Teacher: Fades smooth the start and end of clips. Small removals of breaths or clicks make listening easier.

Checkpoint: You know how fades and small clean-ups improve the listening experience.

Step 2: Do a clean pass

  • Go through the edit and add fades and remove loud breaths or clicks where they distract.

Checkpoint: You completed a clean-up pass on your edit.

Step 3: Final listen

  • Play the whole episode and ask two other teams to listen and give one small polishing suggestion.

Checkpoint: You have final suggestions to make one last tiny improvement.

Your episode is polished. Next, add show notes, the final credits, and export the final file.

planets.title: 11.3: Show Notes, Title Art & Export
planets.missionInstructions:
Show notes tell people what the episode is about and who is in it. Proper exports ensure your teacher and event organisers can play the file easily.

Instructions

Step 1: Write show notes

  • Write a 2–3 sentence show note describing the episode and language(s) used.

Checkpoint: You have clear show notes for the episode.

Step 2: Prepare title art or simple thumbnail

  • Make a simple title card or thumbnail (photo + episode title) using a phone photo app or paper scan.

Checkpoint: You have a simple visual to represent the episode.

Step 3: Export final file and metadata

  • Export the final episode as an MP3 named with team and episode title, and include a small text file with credits and consent details.

Checkpoint: Your final episode and metadata are exported and saved to the teacher area.

The episode file and show notes are ready. Next week you’ll present the episode and reflect on what you learned.
planets.description: Create show notes, a short description, final credits and export the final audio file with the correct name and metadata.
Use the course rubric to self-assess and prepare the rubric submission for teacher grading.
planets.missionInstructions:
Before handing the episode to the teacher for final grading, use your rubric to honestly score your team on the main criteria.

Instructions

Step 1: Micro-teach — Using the rubric

  • Teacher: A rubric helps assess respect & consent, interviewing skills, story clarity, and technical quality.

Checkpoint: You know what the rubric measures.

Step 2: Self-score

  • Use the rubric to score your team on each category and write one example to support each score.

Checkpoint: You completed a self-assessment with evidence for each score.

Step 3: Submit notes to teacher

  • Upload your rubric, final file, show notes, and credits to the teacher area for grading.

Checkpoint: Your materials are submitted and ready for teacher review.

You completed a self-review and submitted materials. Next week you’ll share your episode with the community and reflect.
planets.title: 11.4: Rubric Self-Check

stars.description: Final edits, polish, show notes, episode art/title, and prepare materials for the listening event and rubric submission.

stars.title: Week 12: Share, Reflect & Celebrate

planets.description: Organise a short listening event plan: location, invitations, playback setup, and who will introduce each team’s episode.
planets.title: 12.1: Plan the Listening Event
planets.missionInstructions:
A listening event honours elders and shares the students’ work. Plan a simple program and test equipment for playback.

Instructions

Step 1: Event micro-teach

  • Teacher: A good event has short introductions, clear playback, and time to thank guests.

Checkpoint: You know the basic parts of a respectful listening event.

Step 2: Assign event roles

  • Assign who will introduce the episode, press play, and thank the elder afterward.

Checkpoint: Event roles are assigned for each team.

Step 3: Technical test

  • Test playback of your MP3 on the event equipment and confirm sound levels.

Checkpoint: Your episode plays correctly and levels are set for the room.

The event plan is ready and tested. Next you’ll rehearse your brief introduction for the audience.

A short introduction tells the audience what they’re about to hear and credits the elder in a respectful way.

Instructions

Step 1: Draft intro

  • Write a 30–60 second introduction that includes the team name, episode title, and one sentence about the elder.

Checkpoint: You have a clear short introduction written.

Step 2: Practice delivery

  • Rehearse the introduction aloud with your team and time it to keep it under 60 seconds.

Checkpoint: Your introduction is polished and under time.

Step 3: Prepare thank-you note

  • Prepare a short thank-you to the elder that you will say after playback.

Checkpoint: You have a sincere thank-you prepared for the event.

Your introductions and thanks are ready for the event. Now present your episode with pride.
planets.description: Prepare and practise a 30–60 second introduction for your episode and a thank-you to the elder.
planets.title: 12.2: Rehearse Introductions & Thanks
12.3: Host the Listening Event
planets.description: Play each team’s episode, introduce it, and give the elder (and audience) space to respond if they wish.
planets.missionInstructions:
Today you share your work with elders, families and classmates. Be respectful, listen quietly, and celebrate others after playback.

Instructions

Step 1: Team intro

  • Deliver your 30–60 second introduction to the audience.

Checkpoint: Your team introduced the episode clearly and respectfully.

Step 2: Play episode

  • Play your final exported episode on the tested equipment at a comfortable volume.

Checkpoint: Your episode played smoothly for the audience.

Step 3: Thank and invite brief response

  • Thank the elder and invite a short reaction if they wish; respect if they prefer not to speak.

Checkpoint: You thanked the elder and allowed for a response if desired.

You shared your episode publicly and honoured the elder. Celebrate with your classmates and enjoy the achievements.

Finish the course by reflecting on what you learned, submitting final rubrics, and deciding on community sharing steps that respect elders’ wishes.

Instructions

Step 1: Final rubric and teacher feedback

  • Complete the final rubric with your team and meet the teacher for a short feedback session.

Checkpoint: You finished the rubric and got teacher feedback on your project.

Step 2: Team reflection

  • In your team, list three skills you improved and one thing you’d do differently next time.

Checkpoint: Your team reflected honestly on achievements and next steps.

Step 3: Archive and sharing plan

  • Confirm where the final files will be archived and whether the elder agreed to further sharing; note any restrictions.

Checkpoint: You have a plan to store the episode and know whether it can be shared beyond the event.

You completed the course, shared an elder’s story respectfully, and learned podcasting skills you can use again. Celebrate your work!
planets.title: 12.4: Final Reflection & Next Steps
planets.description: Complete final rubric, reflect on learning, and plan how to archive or share episodes more widely only with elder permission.

stars.description: Host a listening event, reflect on learning, and celebrate the elders and student teams. Collect final rubrics and plan how to share episodes with the wider community if approved.

title: Island Voices: A Young Podcasters’ Guide to Interviewing Elders
description: A 12-week, 4-days-per-week (3 hours/day) hands-on course for 10–13 year olds in the Cook Islands. Teams of 2–4 use smartphones to plan, record, edit, and share one respectful interview podcast with an elder. Focus: critical listening, asking strong questions, active listening, storytelling, and sharing Cook Islands voices in English and/or Cook Islands Māori.
